message.content:
<<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: You can create a custom iterator class that implements the Iterator interface and takes the list of HColumn<ColName, ColValue> as a parameter in its constructor. Here's an example:

public class HColumnIterator<ColName, ColValue> implements Iterator<ColValue> {
    private List<HColumn<ColName, ColValue>> hColumns;
    private int currentIndex;

    public HColumnIterator(List<HColumn<ColName, ColValue>> hColumns) {
        this.hColumns = hColumns;
        this.currentIndex = 0;
    }

    @Override
    public boolean hasNext() {
        return currentIndex < hColumns.size();
    }

    @Override
    public ColValue next() {
        HColumn<ColName, ColValue> hColumn = hColumns.get(currentIndex);
        currentIndex++;
        return hColumn.getValue();
    }
}

Then, you can use this custom iterator to iterate over your list of HColumn<ColName, ColValue> objects and get the corresponding ColValue from each HColumn:

List<HColumn<ColName, ColValue>> hColumns = new ArrayList<>();
// populate the hColumns list

HColumnIterator<ColName, ColValue> iterator = new HColumnIterator<>(hColumns);
while (iterator.hasNext()) {
    ColValue colValue = iterator.next();
    // do something with colValue
}
<<<explanation>>>: By creating a custom iterator class, you can iterate over your list of HColumn<ColName, ColValue> objects and retrieve the corresponding ColValue without creating a new list or modifying the external library. This approach improves performance and efficiency by avoiding unnecessary memory allocation and copying.
